According to reports, four employees of the Pasquotank Correctional Institution were fatally stabbed and several others were wounded during a failed escape attempt by four inmates. The four inmates—Mikel Brady, Wisezah Buckman, Seth Frazier and Jonathan Monk—were charged in connection to the killings. Brady and Buckman have been sentenced to death for their roles in the plot while Frazier and Monk are still awaiting trial as of November 2023.

Arron Lawson shot and stabbed four family members and stabbed another (who survived and alerted the police). Lawson also then sexually abused one of decreased victims. Lawson pleaded guilty and was was sentenced to death.

According to the police, Alec Perez had repeatedly abused his wife, and she had obtained a restraining order against him. He threatened to kill her and told her he'd be back with the right people. He and Rodney Ortiz allegedly murdered her and three others. Both have been charged with trials pending.

According to the authorities, Stephen Paddock, while perched at the window of a Mandalay Bay hotel room, open fired on concert goers below, killing 60 (two of whom died years later from their injuries). Of the 867 injured victims, 411 were injured by gunfire. Paddock took his own life as police approached.
Three known members of the Satan's Disciples gang plus one of their ex-girlfriends were shot in a vehicle by another gang retaliating for a hit two nights earlier. The case is unsolved.

According to the police, Spencer Hight went to his ex-wife's football party and shot her and seven of their friends. All but one of the victims died. Hight was fatally shot at the scene by the police.

Orion Krause abruptly left home in Maine, prompting his mother to call the police, fearing he was going to commit suicide. He later called her and told her he was in Massachusetts, so she drove to pick him up and swung by her parents' house to visit them. Orion called his former college professor to say that he thought he might have to kill his mother. Orion then killed his mother, grandparents, and their caretaker with a baseball bat. He then stripped naked and covered himself in mud, and ran to a neighbor's house to confess. Krause pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life in prison.

Ja'Vonne DuPree was friends with the victims and was staying at their house at the time of the murders. He shot the four victims, ransacked the house, and stole their car. Dupree was convicted and given a life sentence.

According to the police, four men broke into the home of a federally-licensed gun salesman (who ran his business from his home), allegedly killing the salesman, his wife, and a couple that were visiting to play cards. Robbery was the motive and police believe it was gang related. Charges against three of the alleged assailants were dropped, however charges against the fourth--James Powell--stood. Powell took an Alford plea, not admitting guilt, and was given four life sentences without parole eligibility.

Isabel Martinez stabbed her husband and five children to death. After being apprehended, she refused a lawyer and was convicted of murder. Martinez was given a life sentence without parole eligibility.

Damian Herrera got into an argument with his stepfather about using his pickup truck. He then shot and killed his stepfather, his half-brother, and mother when the latter two tried to intervene. His sister escaped. He stole the pickup and fled, eventually killing another man to steal his truck. Herrera then drove to a general store to get gas where he killed another man. He was apprehended after a police chase that ended in a crash. Herrere was convicted and received four consecutive life sentences.

John Neumann was reportedly a disgruntled employee who had a previous history of arguing with coworkers, and even had the police called on him at work ifor battering a coworker; no charges were filed. After being fired from his job, Neumann went back to Fiamma, Inc. and targeted specific coworkers, killing five before himself

Willie Godbolt's wife had left him three weeks prior. He went to her mother's house, where she and their two children were staying, to get custody of the kids back. They called the local deputy, which prompted Godbolt to start firing; he killed three family members and the deputy while his wife and children escaped. He then forced two different individuals to drive him around in different cars, and shot and killed four more people in two homes. He was shot during the process and claimed that his intention had been suicide by cop. Godbolt was found guilty on all charges: four counts of first-degree murder, two counts of kidnapping, one count of attempted murder and one count of armed robbery. He was sentenced to death.

Stanley Ford is accused of setting three fires from 2016 to 2017, including one car fire (no deaths), a house fire that killed two adults, and another house fire of his neighbor that killed seven. Ford was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

A mother and her two children were missing on April 23, 2017. Police found the three of them dead in different locations, as well as the mother's uncle dead in his home. Brian Travis, her supposed live-in boyfriend, confessed to the crimes, pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to life without parole.

According to the authorities, on the evening of April 11, 2017, two female associates of MS-13 lured five young men, including the four victims, to a community park in Central Islip so that Freiry Martinez and other MS-13 members could attack and kill them. The victims were believed to be members of a rival gang who had offended MS-13. Freiry Martinez and numerous other MS-13 members and associates met in the park where they distributed weapons and discussed the plan to kill the victims. Once the female MS-13 associates led the men to a wooded area, Martinez and the other MS-13 members and associates surrounded, attacked and killed of their rivals with machetes, knives, wooden clubs and an axe. The fifth intended victim escaped. The victims’ bodies were discovered the following evening. Martinez, Josue Portillo, and Alexis Hernandez all pleaded guilty and were sentenced to prison; Leniz Escobar was convicted and is awaiting sentencing; and charges against Omar Villalta and Santos Ortiz-Flores are pending. Edwin Rodriguez was extradited back to the U.S. after having fled to El Salvador and plead guilty. He awaits sentencing.

Denver Simmons and Jacob Philip were serving long sentences for double homicide (not together) and decided to kill their dormmates because they were annoying, they were bored, and they wanted to get on death row to end being in prison. Both Simmons and Philip pleaded guilty and were sentenced to life without parole.

Dekitta Holmes was recently divorced with three children and was unemployed despite having a college degree in criminal justice. According to the police, she went to three separate locations to kill her recent boyfriend, sister, and mother and stepfather. Holmes then committed suicide.
Maurice Harris allegedly targeted four people after his father was killed the night before, presumably related to gang violence. Charges against Harris were dropped because of insufficient evidence.

Nengmy Vang was going through a contentious divorce with his wife. He demanded that she immediately grant him the divorce within 24 hours, or he would kill her. He killed two of her coworkers before going to kill her lawyer (Vang’s wife was in hiding at this point). After killing the lawyer, Vang returned home to his apartment and engaged in a three-hour standoff with police, killing a cop before himself being killed. Vang had a history of emotional abuse towards his wife, marital problems, potential mental illness, and financial issues.

Salvador Vasquez-Oliva bludgeoned to death his wife and their two children and fatally stabbed his niece before fleeing to his cousin's house and telling him that he had done something terrible. Vasquez was convicted at trial and sentenced to death.

Armande Tart was a local drug dealer who went to his friend's apartment and killed him after realizing he had used his drugs. He then went to a nearby apartment with other friends, known cocaine dealers, asked to use their bathroom, and then shot them all point blank in the head, presumably stealing the drugs. Tart was convicted and given a life sentence.

Henry Johnson lived in a group home for the mentally ill and got into a fight with either his roommate or landlord. He then set fire in his room as revenge. Five men who also lived in the home perished. Johnson was ruled incompetent to stand trial and sent for psychiatric care.

Karon McVay came to his girlfriend's cousin's house and shot/stabbed four to death, leaving the three-year-old daughter of his girlfriend's cousin alive. He later returned to the scene when police arrived and pretended to be a normal concerned citizen. He had a history of arson and possibly domestic violence, and served time in prison. McVay was convicted and sentenced to life without parole eligibility.

According to the police, Briddell Barber was at a nightclub with his girlfriend when one of the four victims offered her a ride home. This started an altercation with Barber opening fire on this person and his friends. There is no indication that Barber knew any of them. He pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life without parole.

A woman and her son/stepson were killed in their home, which was then burned. Her husband was found the next day in his car, murdered and the car burned as well. Marijuana plants and $60,000 were found in the home. In January 2020, the Kitsap County Sheriff's Office reported that it believes "members and associates" of the Bandidos Motorcycle Club were directly involved in the murders. In 2022, Danie Jay Kelly, Jr., Johnny Watson and Robert Watson were convicted and sentenced to life without parole eligibility.

Opening fire at the Fort Lauderdale International Airport, Esteban Santiago-Ruiz killed five people and wounded six others (dozens more sustained injuries in the ensuing panic). After serving in the military, Santiago-Ruiz became withdrawn and exhibited anger issues. A few months prior to the shooting, he went to the FBI office in Anchorage, Alaska claiming that the government was trying to control his mind. Despite prior gun confiscations due to mental health concerns, he was a legal gun owner and had a concealed carry permit.  Santiago-Ruiz pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life in prison.
According to the police, Keith Kroeker shot his wife and three young children before setting their house and barn ablaze and killing himself.
Dereck Harris allegedly shot and killed four members of a family related to a drug debt. Charges against Harris were dropped because of unreliable and uncooperative witnesses.

Returning after having bought marijuana, Lionel Parks and an accomplice, both armed, ordered everyone in the home to take off their clothes and hand over cellphones, money and jewelry, prosecutors said. They then discovered a woman in a back bedroom with a cellphone and reportedly became "agitated." The two "started executing the victims by shooting them in the head as they were lying on the ground," according to a court document detailing the charges. Four victims died at the scene. There were two survivors of the shooting. One escaped by playing dead and was able to later identify Parks. The other remained on life support, unable to respond to touch or sound, until she died more than 10 months later. Parks was arrested, convicted at trial, and sentenced to life in prison.
Four people were shot dead in a car that had been set on fire; two of the victims were in the trunk, and the other two were in the backseat. The case is unsolved.

A mother tried unsuccessfully to save her four daughters when their house was on fire. The mother survived but the children all perished. It was later determined that the fire was intentionally set, however the identity of the arsonist remains unknown.

Jacob Kosky and Matthew Baker attended a bonfire party in Jackson, Georgia. They left the event for a short while and allegedly killed four people upon their return. Kosky pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life without parole. Baker, who had been charged as an accomplice, was acquitted.

According to the police, Marlon Jones went to a birthday party at a crowded home in Los Angeles and killed a rival Jamaican gang member, resulting in a shootout between rival gangs. Charges against Jones are pending.
Arcan Cetin, an immigrant from Turkey, killed five at the Cascade Mall in Burlington, Washington. A year after being arrested, Cetin hanged himself in his cell.

After serving time for killing his pregnant wife in 1991, Gregory Green married the daughter of the pastor that had helped secure his release. He later tortured and tied her up, making her watch as he killed their children. Green pleaded guilty and was sentenced to prison.

Keandra Austin filed a police report alleging that her neighbor Eric Jackson along with DeEric King had broken into her house. Subsequently, the two men stabbed Austin and then set fire to her house killing her three children. Jackson was arrested in December 2021 and chose to represent himself at trial. He was convicted and sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole. King passed away in 2020 and was never formally charged.

Four men were shot and their bodies burned in a deliberately-set house fire, all believed to be connected to narcotics trafficking. The fire appears to have been set to cover-up the murders.  The case remains unsolved.

A drunken James Steven Jennex sent a text message to a friend apologizing in advance for his actions and then fired a bullet into the heads of each of three developmentally disabled men in his care. He then set his Temecula-area home ablaze and killed himself with a .357 revolver. The fire at the Renee Jennex Small Family Home killed a fourth developmentally disabled man and burned all five bodies beyond recognition.

According to the police, Reginald Hester had made a deal with a woman living in an apartment building to have sex for $10. After taking his money, the woman went back into her apartment and did not come back out. Hester then started a fire that killed four. Hester died from a terminal illness while awaiting trial.

High on meth, Derrick Dearman drove to a home owned by his ex-girlfriend's brother and killed five (including a pregnant woman), before kidnapping his ex-girlfriend and driving her to a relative's home in Mississippi. Dearman pleaded guilty to capital murder charges and a jury then recommended the death penalty.

Dibon Toone beat his wife and their children to death, covering their faces with blankets and clothing. He then stole a company car, drove to Virginia, and turned himself in to police. Toone pleaded guilty to the crimes.
Mark Short killed his wife, three children, and the family dog before committing suicide.

Angry over the recent number of police shootings of unarmed black men, Micah Xavier Johnson targeted white police officers during a public protest in Dallas. He fatally shot five officers and wounded 11 other people (9 officers and two bystanders). Johnson later fled to El Centro College, where he was killed by police using a bomb disposal robot.

Shanynthia Gardner, reportedly suffering from mental illness, fatally stabbed four of her children and superficially cut herself. Her seven-year-old son managed to escape and alert the authorities. Garnder was convicted and given a life sentence with parole eligibility after 51 years..
Jason Dej-Oudom shot and killed his children in their apartment before chasing his wife through parking lots, killing her. He later committed suicide.

A dispute between two homeless men living in a vacant building led one of them, named Johnny Sanchez, to start a fire that not only killed the man he intended to kill, but four others as well. Cadaver dogs found the other homeless victims after the fire was put out. Sanchez was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

A heavily armed gunman shot his way into a gay nightclub killing 49 and injuring 53, many of them critically. The gunman, who was killed by responding SWAT officers, recently pledged allegiance to ISIL.

David Villegas-Hernandez killed his wife and four daughters before fleeing to Mexico where he was apprehended. After extradition back to New Mexico, David Villegas-Hernandez, plead guilty and was given five life sentences. The police believe that a domestic dispute led to the deadly shootings.

Five friends were shot and killed by a friend who then set the house they were staying in on fire. Jeffrey Peacock told investigators he had gone out to get everyone breakfast and when he returned the house was in flames. However, he was convicted and given a life sentence.

Eight family members were shot execution style at four separate locations near their homes in rural Ohio.  The case Involved a custody battle over a three-year-old girl between her mother and her father as well as their respective families. Angela and Edward Wagner pleaded guilty, while George Wagner, IV, was convicted and  sentenced to life without parole. According to Angela Wagner’s testimony during the trial, the family was concerned that the girl was being sexually abused.

A man shot and killed five people in two locations as a result of a domestic dispute before taking his own life as police closed in.  Some of the victims were reportedly members of his estranged wife's family, though she was not among those killed.

A man was lured to the Likquid Lounge because he owed money from a drug deal. Nicholas Tartaglione strangled him. According to the authorities, the victim’s three companions were then taken elsewhere by Tartaglione and his accomplices and were fatally shot, their bodies discovered eight months later. . In 2024, Tartaglione was sentenced to four consecutive life sentences.

In retaliation for the murder of a friend, two gunmen opened fire at a backyard party, killing five and wounding three. Police have determined the suspect with a handgun shot in a manner that forced party-goers towards a gap in a fence where a suspect with an AK-47 rifle waited. The charges against one of the suspects were dropped while the other was acquitted.

Pablo Serrano-Vitorino walked into his neighbor’s house with an assault rifle and opened fire, killing four. He then fled the scene and killed another man in Montgomery County, Missouri, some 170 miles west of Kansas City, KS. He committed suicide while awaiting trial.
A husband shot and killed his wife, her two adopted children from a previous marriage, and a neighbor, before killing himself during a standoff with police. A 12-year-old girl survived unharmed.

A 26-year-old shot and killed his mother, father, and two younger sisters in their family home before being killed by police. The suspect also set the house on fire, impeding police efforts to rescue any potential survivors.

Jason Dalton, a 45-year-old Uber driver, went on a shooting rampage killing six and seriously wounding two others.  According to police, in between the shootings he continued to pick up and deliver passengers to their destinations. Dalton pled guilty and was sentenced to life without parole.

A man and his wife, their granddaughter, and her three-month-old son were found shot to death outside their home. Their bodies had also been set on fire. Grayden Denham was convicted and given four life sentences without parole eligibility plus 115 years.

After a welfare check, police found the bodies of six family members inside their home. Five of the victims, including children ages 10 and 13, died from sharp or blunt force injuries, while the final victim was shot to death. The motive was robbery, and the murders were designed as a cover-up. Diego Uribe Cruz and Jafeth Ramos both pleaded guilty to the murders. Uribe Cruz received a life sentence while Ramos was sentence to 25 years in prison.

While responding to a welfare check, the police found one person dead, and a gunman barricaded in a nearby home. After several hours of negotiations, the police entered the home and found the suspect, Cameron Dooley, dead along with four others. The victims were all relatives of the assailant.

Firefighters responding to a house fire in Rochester, N.Y. discovered four victims and quickly determined the house was a crime scene. No further details are available. police are investigating it as a homicide.

A radicalized Islamic married couple opened fire at a holiday office party in San Bernardino, Calif., killing 14 and injuring 21. They were shot dead by police later that afternoon; an arsenal of weapons, ammunition and bombs were found in their home.

State police found two adults and two children dead. The adults had been shot while the children perished from smoke inhalation from the fire apparently set to cover up evidence of the murders. The assailant, Pascasio Pacheco-Arellano, was convicted and given a life sentence.

Six people were killed while camping on one of the victim's newly purchased land. Four men and a 6-year-old boy were shot after getting help pulling their vehicle out of mud, and a woman was beaten to death. William Hudson was convicted and sentenced to death.

In an attack related to illicit drug trade, three men were shot inside their SUV, which was then burned. Shortly thereafter, a fourth man was shot to death. A crew of six men — five from the Phoenix area and another from Mexico, who prosecutors said was tied to the Sinaloa Cartel — all have been accused of participating in the sprawling murder plot that ultimately left brothers Edgar Berrelleza-Soto, 26, and Joel Mauricio Berrelleza, 35, and two other men dead. Raul Flores was convicted on four counts of first-degree murder and sentenced to life without parole eligibility. Co-defendant Angel De Jesus Barreras is awaiting trial, charged with two counts of voluntary manslaughter. Alejandro Ruiz became a cooperating witness, plead guilty to robbery, and was sentenced to five years in prison. Rosario Roman-Lopez, who allegedly orchestrated the murders, is believed to have been killed in Mexico in retribution. Alexis Corral and Juan Fidencio Castro are charged in connection with the murders but remain at-large.

A married couple and their elderly mothers were shot to death inside their mobile home. Eight years later, Cathy Scott's daughter and son-in-law, Amy and Rosmore Vilardi, were charged in connection with the murders.
Adacia Avery Chambers intentionally drove her vehicle into a crowd at an OSU Homecoming Parade, killing four and injuring many others. She plead "no contest" and received a life sentence.
Police say Glenn Edward Baxter, 27, deliberately drove his estranged wife's SUV into a suburban lake with her and their three young children strapped in their car seats. The whole family drowned.

Christopher Harper-Mercer, 26, opened fire on his writing class at Umpqua Community College in rural Oregon, killing his instructor and eight other people before he was wounded by police. He committed suicide at the scene.

A fire destroyed a rural home, revealing the bodies of a family of six inside. Autopsies led authorities to conclude that Scott Westerhuis had shot and killed his wife and four school-age children and then set fire to their home before killing himself.

Five family members were found dead in their home. Authorities said Brian S. Short, 45, killed his wife and teenagers before killing himself. Acquaintances and family members said Short was depressed because his Internet business was struggling.

Deputies arrested David Conley on capital murder charges after a standoff at a home he once shared with a woman he dated. The woman, her husband and six children were found dead inside. Conley also faced earlier assault charges against the same female victim. He was convicted of murder and sentenced to life without parole.

Jody Herring, 40, was tackled by onlookers after he fatally shot a social worker outside a state office building. She had handled a case involving Herring's daughter. Hours later, three of Herring's relatives were found shot dead in their home. Herring pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life without parole.

Bigamist Christopher M. Henderson and wife Rhonda Carlson were charged with murder in the deaths of another wife, her mother and two children. The victims' bodies were found in their burning house. The woman had recently filed for a protective order. Henderson was convicted and sentenced to death, while Carson pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life without parole.

Robert Bever, 18, and Michael Bever, 16, were arrested after police found five of their family members stabbed dead in their home. A 13-year-old girl was injured in the attack; a 2-year-old was unharmed. Both teens were convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

Hours after police responded to a domestic violence call at the home, the estranged husband shot his wife and her two children, as well as her father. The father survived until Dec. 4, 2015, making him the fourth death. The offender took his own life.

Police were preparing to arrest Martin Martinez in connection with the 2014 death of his 2-year-old son when they were called to a home and found Martinez's former girlfriend, her mother, and three children--including Martinez's infant daughter--dead. Martinez pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life without parole.

The bodies of a woman and her three children were found decomposing inside their fire-damaged home. It was unclear when they died. Medical examiners determined the woman had been strangled to death and the children died from smoke inhalation. The case is unsolved.

Four Marines and a Naval officer died when a gunman attacked a military training center after having shot up a military recruitment office earlier. Mohammod Youssuf Abdulazeez, 24, was killed by a police officer at the scene.

Authorities responding to shots fired at a rural residence found a man dead in the front yard and a woman and two teenagers shot dead inside. An 8-year-old boy was taken to the hospital. Four men were arrested in connection to the crime. Joseph Smith, Antly Scott and Robert Bailey were convicted and sentenced to life in prison, while Derrick Coleman received a sentence of two years in prison after having testified against his co-defendants.

A white gunman killed nine people, including a pastor, attending a prayer meeting at a historic black church. Dylann Storm Roof, 21, was charged with murder and federal hate crimes. He was convicted and sentenced to death.

Jordyn D. Wade , 16, and Robert Lee Adams Jr., 27, were charged with murder and kidnapping in the deaths of two men and two women. Adams fled the state but was arrested months later in Mississippi. He was then convicted and sentenced to life without parole. Wade was convicted and sentenced to 172 years in prison.

Michael Augustine Bournes killed his wife and toddler inside their remote cabin, then went outside and shot his two young sons. He brought their bodies inside, lay them down together, and then set the building on fire and shot and killed himself.

A meeting between five biker gangs at a restaurant escalated into a shootout that killed nine gang members and wounded 18. Police arrested 177 people and found more than 300 weapons, including an AK-47. Officers received and returned gunfire in the melee. After four years, the murder charges were dropped.

Police arrested Daron Dylan Wint, whose DNA was found on a pizza crust inside the home of a local CEO. Authorities believe the CEO, his wife, 10-year-old son and housekeeper were held captive before they were killed, and their house set ablaze.  The prosecution had maintained that the motive for the gruesome murders was greed. All four victims were killed despite a $40,000 ransom being dropped off at the home by the CEO’s assistant. Wint had thousands of dollars in cash in his possession when he was arrested.  Wint was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.
A man diagnosed with bipolar disorder and schizophrenia shot his parents, brother and 17-year-old niece at the family's longtime home. He killed himself before police arrived.

A dispute over how to run the family limousine business ended with Driss Diaeddinn shooting his two brothers, mother, and sister-in-law at home. His wife and children escaped. Diaeddinn held police at bay for hours before committing suicide.

Three women and a man were found shot "execution style" in a home on the northwest side of Indianapolis. Police said someone had forced entry, and that the killings were not random. Nicholas Dunn, 36, was arrested for the crime in 2019. However, the charges against him were later dropped because of "significant evidentiary challenges."

Police found eight people shot, seven fatally, in four homes at a rural crossroads. Police said they suspected Joseph Aldridge, 36. He was soon found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot in his pickup truck on a road about 15 miles east.

According to the police, Cedric Prather approached his ex-wife's home and began shooting. He killed her, another man, and two children, and also wounded two more children before shooting himself fatally.

Thomas Jesse Lee pleaded guilty but mentally ill to five counts of malice murder in the slayings of his wife, her parents, her daughter and a family friend. Their bodies were found at a home where Lee had been staying. Lee is sentenced to life in prison.

A fire set to a one-room trailer concealed the fact that a woman and her three young children were stabbed to death inside. Authorities had gone to the home twice the day before because of a domestic dispute. Husband/father Jonathan Camacho was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

Four men were fatally shot inside a stolen car that was double-parked on the street. The San Francisco police characterized the incident as a case of gang retaliation in culmination of a long-running feud. Lee Farley, 26, was arrested in connection with the shootings.

Late on a Saturday night, neighbors heard pounding on a door, then the sound of someone breaking in, then gunshots. Police found the bodies of a woman, her two young sons, and her boyfriend. Calvin Carter, the woman's ex-boyfriend, was charged with the murders, convicted, and sentenced to life in prison.

Six people were killed at three locations in suburban Philadelphia. After a daylong manhunt, police found the body of suspect Bradley William Stone, a former Marine, in the woods near his home. Stone's ex-wife and five of her family members died.

Police said Jody Hunt, 39, drove to three locations around Morgantown and shot an ex-girlfriend, a cousin, and two other acquaintances. He was found that evening in his pickup truck, an apparent suicide. Hunt, a convicted felon, bought his handgun online.

A 9-year-old girl survived a gunshot to call police about a shooting that left five dead at a Wade Park home. James E. Sparks-Henderson was arrested six months later and charged with aggravated murder. He was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

Four acquaintances who had been staying together at an Economy Inn were shot in their room on a Saturday morning. Three died at the scene; a fourth died of his injuries several days later. Scott A. Goodwin-Bey was charged with four counts of murder. Investigators believed Goodwin-Bey thought one or all of the victims told police about his drug use.

Police originally described the slayings of a couple, their daughter, and a family acquaintance as a murder/suicide. But six days later authorities charged Ryan Champion, the couple's adult son, with four counts of murder in the shootings. He was convicted and sentenced to life.
A 15-year-old used text messages to draw several cousins and friends to his cafeteria table at Marysville-Pilchuck High School. He shot five, four of them fatally, before killing himself.

Four children, their mother and grandfather died in a house fire that critically injured their father. Court documents say Ryan Williams was angry that the father had turned him in to police on a theft charge. Williams was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.
The bodies of two adults and two young boys were found in their home. They had been stabbed and bludgeoned to death. The case is unsolved.

Don Charles Spirit called police to say he had killed his adult daughter and six grandchildren, ages 3 months to 11 years, and then killed himself. Authorities had investigated the family for child abuse and neglect charges 18 times from 2006 to 2014.

Timothy Ray Jones, Jr. led investigators to the bodies of his five children, ages 1 through 8, buried off a dirt road in Alabama. According to police, the children died days earlier in Lexington County, SC. Jones was convicted and sentenced to death.

A 27-year-old woman, her new boyfriend, and her parents were found buried a mile from their home. Adam Matos, her former boyfriend who lived with the family, was convicted and sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

Police said Brandon Howell severely beat an elderly couple and fatally shot three neighbors. The couple died a week later. Howell faced a dozen charges, including three counts of first-degree murder. He was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

The Santa Barbara County sheriff said dispatchers received a call from a man who calmly told them he had just stabbed his parents and two sons at the home they all shared. Nicholas Holzer was convicted and sentenced to life.

A family member found a couple and their three girls shot dead inside their home. The Culpeper County sheriff said the deaths were apparently a murder-suicide resulting from a "domestic situation" between the two adults.

According to a medical examiner's report, Joel Smith, 33, had sought help for anxiety but was not taking antidepressants because he had lost his insurance. Smith shot his wife, stepson, and two children before killing himself.

Jonathan Rosa and Cornelius Crawford forced a real estate agent into her SUV and sexually assaulted her as they drove off in the vehicle. They lost control of the vehicle and crashed into the fruit stand, striking a family of four. The three children were killed immediately, and their mother died weeks later from her injuries. Rosa and Crawford both pleaded guilty and were sentenced to prison.

A man bound and fatally shot six members of a family in their home. A seventh, wounded, played dead and then alerted police, who arrested Ronald Haskell, 33, in a nearby neighborhood after a four-hour standoff. Tried for murder in 2019, Haskell was sentenced to death.

Sonny Enrique Medina, 36, fatally shot his common-law wife and their three daughters, ages 10, 6 and 2, and then took his own life. The woman had talked about leaving Medina, according to a police report. She was found with numerous bruises on her arms and face.

A 22-year-old college student frustrated over sexual rejections promised in a video to "annihilate" women "on the day of retribution." Elliot Rodger, who was found dead, is suspected of killing six (3 by shooting and 3 by stabbing) and wounding seven others.

A 67-year-old woman and her daughter, granddaughter and great-grandson were found after a house fire. They had been stabbed or died in the blaze. Alexander Hill Jr., who was arrested a year later in Buffalo, was charged with four counts of murder. He was convicted and sentenced to life.

According to the police, Cherie Rhodes used a handgun to shoot five people, four of them fatally, during a tribal eviction hearing  at an American Indian headquarters in Northern California . She also used a butcher knife to wound a sixth person before being subdued. Rhodes was convicted and sentenced to death.

Two men and two women were found shot in a small house in the Southeast side neighborhood. Police said this occurred during a robbery of money and illegal drugs. Kenneth Rackemann was convicted and sentenced to life without parole, while Samatha Bradley, Valencia Williams, and Anthony Larussa were also convicted and received prison sentences of varying lengths.

A petroleum industry engineer, his wife and two young sons were found shot in their home about a week after they were last seen alive.  Eight years later, Feng Lu, a former business associate of one of the victims, was arrested for the shootings.
At their home in Spanish Fork, Utah, a police officer shot his wife, two young children, his mother-in-law and himself.

After finding a woman in an alley with gunshot wounds, police found her car and then her house half a mile away, where her brother, ex-husband and another woman lay dead of gunshots. The first victim died two days later. No arrests have been made.

A nurse and her three children -- ages 4, 6 and 9 -- were reported missing after the mom didn't show up for work. Their bodies were found in their home. David Cornell Bennett, Jr., a former boyfriend, pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life without parole.

Police are searching for a suspect after four adults were found shot inside a Tulsa home. Six children were unharmed and placed in foster care. The house had been the scene of several drug arrests in the past year, police said.

Authorities have made no arrests in the case of two sisters and two men shot to death inside a home in Jacksonville's Murray Hill neighborhood. There was no sign of forced entry. Three died at the scene, while a fourth died at the hospital.

Police were called by a man saying he wanted to hurt himself. After failing to make contact with anyone inside the home, a SWAT team discovered the bodies of five victims, two of them children. Bryan E. Sweatt, 27, had committed suicide.

Charles Everett Brownlow Jr., 36, is charged with killing five people in three separate homes and a convenience store over a span of six hours. He was arrested after being chased in a vehicle and on foot. He was convicted and sentenced to death, but his sentenced was reduced to life without parole after the state's death penalty was declare unconstitutional.

An itinerant man is charged with stabbing his cousin's wife and her four children after briefly staying with the family. Police found Mingdong Chen at the scene covered in blood. Chen pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 125 years to life in prison.
Michael Guzzo, 56, used a shotgun to kill the family next door -- a man, his daughter, her husband, and their son. He also killed two of their five dogs. He then returned home and killed himself.

A woman called police to report that she heard "someone got shot." Responding officers found four men dead inside the house. Police said the shooting did not appear to be random, but they have made no arrests.

A couple and their three children were found shot in their home. Authorities said Guadalupe Ronquillo-Ovalle killed her spouse and children, then herself. Her husband had been arrested Sept. 11 on a family violence assault charge.
Aaron Alexis, 34, killed 12 and injured eight in an office building at the Washington Navy Yard. The former Navy reservist was killed by police. Alexis worked for a base subcontractor.

Authorities said three teens and a young woman were shot in a car. Jacob Allen Bennett was convicted and sentenced to life without parole. His girlfriend, Brittany Moser, pleaded guilty to facilitation of second degree murder and received a ten-year prison sentence.

Daniel Green, who was diagnosed with schizophrenia and had stopped taking his meds allegedly killed his mother, sister, niece and nephew in their Oklahoma City home in 2013.  Murder charges were dismissed in 2016 after Green was found incompetent to stand trial. However, in 2022, after he was declared competent, murder charges were refiled.

Erbie Bowser faces capital murder charges in the slayings of his ex-girlfriend and her daughter in Dallas. Bowser was arrested 15 minutes away, inside the home of his ex-wife, who was found shot dead with her adult daughter. Four children were injured. Bowser was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

Police say the 4:30 a.m. fatal shooting of two men, one of whom reportedly owed the assailant money, appeared to be drug-related. Also killed were a father and son newspaper delivery team that just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time. Sidney A. Muller was charged with four counts of first-degree murder. He was convicted and given a life sentence.

Pedro Alberto Vargas, 42, set a fire in his apartment and shot the building managers who came to see what was wrong. He then shot a man on the street and a family of three before taking two tenants hostage. After negotiations failed, police killed him.

A domestic shooting turned public when John Zawahri, 23 left home where had killed his father and older brother, carjacked a woman, shot at other vehicles, and then entered the campus of Santa Monica College with a semiautomatic rifle that he assembled from a kit. There he killed four others. Police shot Zawahri in a standoff in the school's library.

Samuel Sallee was found guilty of four counts of murder. The sheriff said methamphetamine was found at the rural home where a couple and two of their friends had been shot. Sallee was sentenced to life in prison.

Four children sleeping upstairs died after the house was set on fire. Four people, including the children's parents, were able to escape from the lower floors. Derrick J. Twardoski pleaded guilty to one count of murder and received a 53-year sentence.

Rick Odell Smith, 43, was shot by police shortly after the slayings of five family members. Smith carried an injured 6-year-old next door and asked neighbors to take her to the hospital. He had been in a custody dispute with a relative of the victims.

Three neighbors who tried to intervene in a domestic dispute were killed after a gunman shot a woman inside an apartment. Dennis Clark III, the woman's live-in boyfriend, was killed by police in the complex's parking lot.

Derrick Brantley and Deshanon Haywood were charged in the execution-style killings of four people in a townhouse in a public-housing complex. Brantley and Haywood were each sentenced to life in prison.

Kurt Myers, 64, shot four people, two fatally, at a barbershop In Mohawk, NY before killing two others at a car wash in the next town of Herkimer. He held police in an overnight standoff before they swarmed and killed him. Authorities do not know what provoked the attacks.

Nehemiah Griego, the 15-year-old son of a pastor,  was charged as an adult for using his parents' guns to shoot his mother, father and three siblings. According to the police, Griego claimed he wanted to die while in a gunfight with authorities. He was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

Two brothers, Cedric and James Poore, were each charged with four counts of murder and two counts of robbery in the slayings of four women inside an apartment. According to the police, robbery was the motive. The two assailants were both convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

Adam Lanza, 20, killed his mother at their Newtown, Conn., home, then drove to nearby Sandy Hook Elementary School. He forced his way in and killed six adults and 20 children with a rifle, firing 154 shots. He killed himself with a handgun.

Hector Celaya was in a lengthy custody dispute involving his three children. He shot his mother, two uncles and son on the Tule Indian Reservation before fleeing with two daughters. Before he was shot by police, Celaya shot both girls, killing one.

No arrests have been made in the slayings of four people ages 16 to 34 inside a Detroit home. The day after the bodies were found, the house was torched by an arsonist and destroyed. Investigators say the murders may be drug related.

Four adults were shot dead in the front yard of an unlicensed boarding house in the Northridge neighborhood of Los Angeles. Ka Pasasouk, on probation at the time, was arrested the next day in Las Vegas. It is believed that he killed one of the victims as part of a robbery and then the other three to eliminate witnesses. Pasasouk was sentenced to death.

Kalcie Eagle, 21, lived a block away from the family he is accused of killing. A grandmother and three of her grandchildren were shot in their home. A 12-year-old who played dead called 911. Eagle stabbed himself to death in front of police hours later.

Officials said a financial dispute resulted in two men killing girlfriends and others connected with a drug ring associate. Zakkawanda Moss was convicted and sentenced to life in prison. Henry Lee Burrell was convicted and sentenced to life.

Firefighters responding to a blaze at Fero's Bar & Grill found five people inside stabbed to death. Joseph Hill pleaded guilty to murder and received a life sentence. His brother Lynell was sentenced to 70 years. Dexter Lewis was sentenced to life.
After he was fired from a Minneapolis sign company, Andrew J. Engeldinger shot and killed five people before killing himself.

Wade M. Page, 40, lead guitarist in a white-power band named End Apathy, entered a Sikh temple in Oak Creek, Wis., and killed six with a handgun. He wounded three, including a police officer. After police shot Page in the stomach, he killed himself. One of the injured died eight years later from complications related to the injuries.

James E. Holmes opened fire in an Aurora, Colo., movie theater, killing 12 and injuring 70. Holmes, who had pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity, was found guilty of first-degree murder. He was sentenced to life in prison.

A 5-year-old boy escaped and told neighbors that "Daddy's dead" right after Robert Brazzon had shot his ex-brother-in-law, his wife, and their teenage son. Brazzon earlier had killed his live-in girlfriend. Brazzon shot himself after a brief standoff with police.

Dealing with a brain tumor and facing a bitter divorce, James Butwin killed his wife and three children, loaded their bodies in an SUV, took it to the desert and set it on fire. A business partner called police after finding "blood everywhere" at the family's home. Butwin committed suicide.
Ian Lee Stawicki, 40, entered a Seattle coffee shop and shot and killed four. He then killed a woman for her car, leading police on a chase that ended with Stawicki killing himself.

Nikolay Lazukin shot his wife and two daughters, suffocated his infant and set the house ablaze. He also used a baseball bat to kill a neighbor who was walking nearby. Lazukin killed himself after sending an apologetic text message to his father-in-law.

The bodies of a man, his girlfriend and two children were found naked in the woods a mile from their vehicle. Police said the killings occurred over a drug debt. James Roy Belknap received a life sentence for four counts of first-degree murder.

Tonya Thomas killed her four teenage and pre-teen children, shooting them a total of 18 times before killing herself. Three of the kids went to a neighbor's house to say their mother shot them, but Thomas called them back inside.

Jason "J.T." Ready, a well-known white supremacist who had run for public office, shot his girlfriend, three of her family members and then himself. In February, police told Ready's girlfriend to get a protective order against him; she declined.

A former nursing student is accused of using a handgun to kill seven at Oikos University, a small private college in East Oakland. One Goh has been treated in a state mental hospital ever since, but in October 2015 was deemed competent to stand trial. Goh pleaded "no contest," was given seven consecutive life sentences. Goh died in prison in 2019.

Five people were killed in their home with what prosecutors described as a "blunt instrument." No motive has been revealed. Binh Thai Luc, 35, pleaded not guilty to five counts of murder, robbery, burglary and lying in wait. He was convicted and sentenced to life.

Jeong Soo Paek entered his sisters' suburban Atlanta spa and shot them and their husbands before killing himself. In 2006, one sister had gotten a temporary restraining order against Paek, who had threatened to harm them with guns at the salon.

Five men playing poker inside a Birmingham home were shot to death. Police said the slayings started as a robbery. Reginald Mims  sentenced to 25 years. Artavius Underwood and Rashad Stoves were both sentenced to life in prison for the murders, while Reginald Mims  received a 25 year prison sentence.

A man facing prison described himself as despondent before he shot his girlfriend and three teenage relatives as they slept. Cedric Anderson, who a month earlier had been found guilty of heroin possession, set the house afire and then committed suicide.

A family had just finished opening Christmas presents when a relative dressed as Santa Claus opened fire, killing six before shooting himself. Azizolah "Bob" Yazdanpanah faced foreclosure and had recently separated from his wife, one of the victims.

Sara McMeen, 30, struggled with bipolar disorder and postpartum depression. She shot her live-in boyfriend, two children and her 10-month-old daughter before killing herself. Forty years before, her father shot his first wife in a schizophrenic episode.

Esteban Quintero Gonzales forced his way into a trailer and shot and killed four people inside, including his two children and their mother, before killing himself. The couple had been involved in an ongoing custody dispute, sheriff's deputies said.

Jose Avila-Alva's wife refused to file domestic assault charges after an incident the week before. He opened fire on his four children in the family's front yard, killing them and committing suicide. His wife was injured but survived the shooting.

Forty hours after gaining custody of her deceased sister's three children, Mary Ann Holder shot and killed two of them, along with two of her own as well as her son's girlfriend. Police said the stress of the custody case, along with an ended affair, contributed. Holder committed suicide.

Matthew Denton, 17, drove his Chevrolet Suburban at 97 mph into a Dodge Caravan moving at 50-55 mph., killing himself and those in the other vehicle: a woman, her ex-husband, their son, and his girlfriend. The coroner ruled the act a murder-suicide.

Susan Hendricks received four life sentences after pleading guilty but mentally ill to the slayings of her two sons, her ex-husband, and another family member. Hendricks, who suffered from multiple mental illnesses, committed the crimes for insurance money.

Police say a custody battle may have sparked the fatal shooting of eight people at a beauty salon. Scott Dekraai pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life without parole in the slayings of his ex-wife and others, including a man parked outside the shop.

David Ison will serve life in prison in the fatal shootings of five people in a rural part of Indiana. According to police reports, Ison had previously purchased drugs from one of his victims. They fought over the price of the prescription medication.

Eduardo Sencion entered an IHOP and fired about 60 rounds from an AK-47, killing three off-duty uniformed National Guard members and another patron. Seven others, including two National Guard members, were injured. Sencion shot himself in the head.

Shayne Riggleman, 22, had been diagnosed as bipolar. He killed five people -- family and friends of a couple who had taken in his ex-girlfriend. He then hit a woman with his car and shot a gas station attendant before killing himself.

Leonard Egland killed his estranged wife, her boyfriend, and the man's son. He took his own daughter, age 7, to Bucks County, PA, where he killed his mother-in-law, dropped his daughter at a hospital, wounded two policemen, and escaped. He later killed himself that night.

John Ragin's wife had taken out a protective order against him, but police hadn't served it before they found her and three of their children stabbed to death. Ragin was convicted of capital murder and sentenced to life in prison.

Using two handguns, Michael Hance went on a shooting spree, killing seven neighbors and relatives of his live-in girlfriend. His girlfriend was injured in the attack. Police fatally shot Hance outside a suburban home 10 minutes after the shooting began.

Rescue units responding to a house fire found four bodies inside. All four, two of whom were children, had been shot. James Bannister, the boyfriend of one of the victims. was convicted and given a life sentence for the murders

In a protective-order affidavit, Tan Do's wife said he threatened to kill her when she tried to leave him. However, she then asked that the order be dismissed. Months later, Do shot and killed her, four of her relatives and himself at their son's birthday party.

In his sentencing hearing, Jordan Adam Criado said he killed his wife only after she killed the couple's four children. Yet a judge said evidence was "overwhelming" that Criado had stabbed and smothered his kids. Criado was sentenced to life in prison.

After a lengthy mental evaluation, Everett Conant III was ruled competent. He pleaded no contest to murder in the killings of his three sons and their uncle, and one count of attempted murder in the shooting of his wife. He was sentenced to five life terms without possibility of parole.

Rodrick Shonte Dantzler shot himself at the end of a rampage that took the lives of seven people, including his wife, her parents, their daughter, and an ex-girlfriend. Dantzler had a history of threats against women, according to court records.

A 7-year-old girl watched as her mother was shot. She then grabbed her brother and walked four miles to a neighbor's house to call 911. Kenneth Lee Myers, 47, shot his wife (the girl's mother), two relatives, and an ex-girlfriend before he killed himself.

A pharmacy robbery ended with David Laffer shooting four people, including two store employees, before fleeing with 10,000 hydrocodone pills. His wife, a painkiller addict, drove the getaway car. Laffer received four life sentences without parole, and she received a 25-year sentence for her role.

One morning, four years after his fifth divorce, Carey Hal Dyess, 73, drove around Yuma County, shooting six people, five of them fatally: his latest ex-wife, three of her friends, and her divorce lawyer. He then pulled over and killed himself.
Gaylin Leirmoe fatally shot his two sons, their mother, and her sister at their home before setting fire to it and killing himself.

Randle Lee Roberts spared the life of an 8-year-old girl but gunned down the rest of her family, including her mother and 11-year-old sister, as they slept. Roberts fled but was killed in a shootout with police later that day.

Tuan Dao, 37, had separated from his wife and was facing financial problems. His wife had gotten a protective order against him. He and his five children, ages 6 to 12, died in a fire he set in their home. An older daughter and his wife were not home.

Alan Atwater, 31, used a .22-caliber rifle to shoot his wife and three children, ages 1, 2, and 4, then himself. She had told him and her friends that she wanted to separate, according to court documents.

Maksim Gelman was sentenced to 200 years in prison in connection to a daylong string of stabbing attacks and carjackings. Four people died and four were injured. A manhunt for Gelman ended when police arrested him in Times Square.
Three brothers and a cousin were shot on their patio while watching a Los Angeles Lakers game on TV. Police have said the shooting is gang related. It has not been solved.

An oilfield worker killed the mother of his child, then went across town to kill her brother, her mother, and her mother's boyfriend. Omar Kalmio, 27, spared his infant daughter. He will remain in prison for life without the chance for parole.

Jared Lee Loughner went to an event for Rep. Gabrielle Giffords and shot her and constituents waiting to speak with her. Six died and 13 others, including Giffords, were hurt. Loughner pleaded guilty in 2013 to avoid the death penalty and was sentenced to life without parole.

Nathan Fortner's ex-girlfriend and two of her relatives were shot dead at their home. The body of a fourth victim was found in an abandoned house where the ex-girlfriend said Fortner had sexually assaulted her just days before. Fortner committed suicide.

Police arrested Henry Segura in Minnesota 10 months after his ex-girlfriend and three children were found dead in their home. The ex-girlfriend and one of her children were shot at their Saddle Creek Run home. The other children were drowned and all three were left in a partially filled bathtub. Before the killings, Segura had been ordered to pay back $20,000 in child support for his son. He was convicted of murder and sentenced to life without parole eligibility.

An $1,800 robbery ended in the shootings of five people, four fatally, in a home invasion in the Mattapan neighborhood of Boston. Dwayne Moore received a sentence of life in prison without parole eligibility. Kimani Washington struck a deal, pleading guilty in exchange for a lesser sentence of 16-18 years in prison. Edward Washington was acquitted.

Police came upon Patrick Dell, 32, as he shot himself on the front steps of his estranged wife's home. Inside, officers found the wife and four of her children shot dead. A fifth boy, 12, was wounded. Dell's biological children were unharmed.

When Stanley Neace's wife didn't cook his eggs the way he wanted, he became enraged and fatally shot her and her daughter, and then went to other trailer homes and shot three neighbors. Neace, 47, killed himself with a shotgun.

Lee Roy Williams told police in a recorded interview that he ''snapped'' after learning his roommates planned to evict him. He pleaded guilty to four counts of murder in the slayings of two men and two women and received four consecutive life sentences.

Police tailing suspects in a series of drug-related robberies found four men bound and fatally shot in a garage after the suspects had fled. Police killed one of the perpetrators, Arturo Ibarra, after a chase. Raul Segura-Rodriguez, the other perpetrator, has since been convicted of a 2011 double homicide but still awaits trial for the quadruple garage murder.

Brian Diez, 26, barged into his ex-girlfriend's house, shot dead five adults, and took his two young children. He brought the kids to a relative in California before committing suicide. His ex, who was killed, had a restraining order against Diez.

Ricardo M. McCray was sentenced to life without parole eligibility in connection with a shooting outside of a popular bar in downtown Buffalo. Four people were killed, including a man celebrating his wedding anniversary. Four others were injured, with one sustaining injuries so serious that remained hospitalized for a lengthy period of time.

Police found the bodies of two women and two children in a trash-filled garage apartment. Darrell Lynn Bellard was convicted and sentenced to life in prison without parole eligibility. Tkeisha Nicole Gilmer pleaded guilty in 2011 and was sentenced to life.

Just after Omar S. Thornton was forced to resign from his beer delivery job, he opened fire with a 9 mm pistol, killing eight co-workers and injuring two before killing himself. Supervisors had confronted Thornton over pilferage.

Investigators at first thought four children and their mother had died in an accidental house fire. But they discovered the kids had been killed -- three had slashed throats -- by their mother Leisa Jones, 30, who died of smoke inhalation.
Police found three people bleeding from fatal stab wounds, and another body in the basement. Michael Eric Ballard, who had served time for killing a man in 1991, was sentenced to death.

Gerardo Regalado's wife had moved out and started a new job. The couple fought in the parking lot, where he shot her, and then he ran into the restaurant where she worked, targeting women. Four died and three were injured. Regalado committed suicide.

Thomas Mortimer IV admitted killing his wife, two young children and mother-in-law and was sentenced to four life terms without parole. According to a letter Mortimer wrote that was found at the scene, he hated his wife's parents, with whom he lived.

Aunterrio Barney was arrested in North Carolina months after a purposely set fire killed three adults and a 2-year-old boy. Barney had faced the death penalty, but because Illinois has banned it, he now will serve a mandatory life sentence.

James Larry told police he was angry his family were infidels who would not conform to his Muslim culture. He shot and killed his pregnant wife, young son and three other family members. He pleaded guilty and was imprisoned without possibility of parole.

A gathering of acquaintances at a North Hollywood Mediterranean restaurant ended when a man left and returned with a handgun, firing 50 bullets, killing four and injuring two. Nerses Galstyan was charged with four counts of murder and received a life sentence without parole eligibility.

The theft of a cheap bracelet ended in three shootings, including a drive-by that sprayed bullets at a funeral crowd, killing four teens. Jeffrey Best, Robert Bost and Orlando Carter were sentenced to life without parole. Nathaniel Simms, Lamar Williams and Sanquan Carter received prison sentences of 25, 30 and 54 years, respectively.

Damian Jordan had a history of violence against women, with multiple arrests for battery. He pleaded guilty to four counts of manslaughter in the shootings of his girlfriend, her sister and her two children. Jordan was sentenced to 80 years in prison.

Prosecutors say recordings show a landlord told his handyman to torch a wood-frame house. The fire trapped three adults and four kids in the attic. Lawrence Myers was sentenced to life in prison; maintenance man Marion Cormier was convicted and sentenced to life in prison.

A couple and their two young sons vanished from their home in 2010. In November 2013, authorities discovered their bodies in shallow graves outside Victorville, CA, and a year later charged one victim's business partner, Charles Merritt, with murder. He was convicted and sentenced to death.

A toilet paper roll drenched in paint thinner, set ablaze and thrown at the bottom of a crowded Brooklyn tenement's stairs trapped five victims. Daniel Ignacio received 25 years to life in prison. Officers testified that Ignacio told them he was drunk.
Christopher Brian Speight was arrested and charged with killing eight relatives and friends. Speight pleaded guilty and received five life sentences plus 18 years in prison.

Following a family feud, 20-year-old Maron Thomas fatally shot his mother, stepfather, pregnant sister, brother, and two-year-old niece (who he also decapitated). Thomas was tried and convicted of murder and then sentenced to life without parole eligibility.

On January 12, 2010, three people were killed and two others critically injured in a workplace shooting at a truck rental business located near Kennesaw, GA.  Another victim died in 2013 from complications related to his injuries. The shooter, a former employee Jesse J. Warren, was found incompetent to stand trial in 2017.

Tyrone M. Adair, 38, shot himself four days after police found his girlfriend's and infant daughter's bodies in the trunk of his car. His ex-girlfriend and a 2-year-old daughter were shot at their home. Adair was out of work and faced child support costs.

Maurice Clemmons killed four Lakeview, Washington police officers with a handgun as they were working on their laptops at a Parkland coffee shop. Two days later, Clemmons was killed at a traffic stop by a Seattle officer. Multiple people were convicted for helping Clemmons's attempt to flee

James Kraig Kahler lost his high-paying job after his arrest for domestic assault. His wife of 23 years described him as controlling. He was convicted of killing his wife, two daughters, and his wife’s grandmother. His son, 10, was not injured. Kahler was convicted and was sentenced to death.

Paul Merhige, 35, had been treated for depression and obsessive-compulsive disorder. At Thanksgiving dinner, he shot his aunt, twin sisters and cousin and wounded two others. He pleaded guilty to avoid the death penalty and will spend life in prison.

Five adults were found dead in two trailers that had been burglarized, with one trailer being set on fire, and three men were implicated in the crime.  Marvin Stinger was killed by police, Jeremy Pickney received a 50-year sentence for burglary charges, and Samuel Lee Conway was convicted in 2011, before having the conviction overturned. In a 2016 retrial, Conway pleaded guilty to lesser charges and received  40-year sentences for each of the five murders to run concurrently.

Four people (two of whom were pregnant) were killed in a drug dispute implicating four assailants. David Allen Tyner and Johnathan Cochran both pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against Denny Phillips and Russell Hogshooter. Tyner was sentenced to six life terms and Cochran to 25 years. Phillips and Hogshooter were convicted at trial and received life sentences.
Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, an Army psychiatrist, was sentenced to death in shootings at Fort Hood. He entered a military medical center firing a semi-automatic pistol, killing 13 and injuring 32.

A romantic dispute led Marcos Chavez Gonzalez to kill four people with a high-powered assault rifle. The victims were his girlfriend's adult relatives and friends. Gonzalez pleaded guilty and was sentenced to three life terms without parole eligibility.

A husband, wife and their three children were bludgeoned with a tire iron. Their former son-in-law, Christopher Harris, did it, according to his brother Jason, who admitted that he watched. Prison sentences: Life and 20 years, respectively.
Mesac Damas slashed the throats of his wife and five children and later fled to Haiti. He was found competent to stand trial and subsequently was sentenced to death.

Eight family members, seven of them adults, were beaten to death in a mobile home. A child was injured. Guy Heinze Jr., who reported the slayings to police, was found guilty of eight counts of murder and sentenced to life in prison without parole.

Richard Terrance Ringold, 44, fatally shot his girlfriend, Atania Butler, and three of her house mates. Butler’s 4-year-old daughter was also shot but survived. Ringold pleaded guilty to four counts of murder and was sentenced to life without parole eligibility.

Four residents of an apartment building died in a fire set in the laundry room. A resident heard saying he hated the place was tried twice on homicide and arson charges. The jury deadlocked both times. Charges have been dropped. The case remains open.

Jacob Levi Shaffer is serving life sentences for killing six people, including his estranged wife and her teenage son. Hours before killing his wife's family, he beat a man to death at an Alabama marble company owned by his wife's relatives.

Adrian Burks went to the house where his girlfriend was staying, got in an argument, and killed her and the other three people who lived there, including a 3-year-old girl. He pleaded guilty to the four shootings and received life in prison.

Faced with the possibility of his wife leaving him, Christopher A. Wood shot her and their three young children. He then wrote suicide notes and mutilated the bodies before committing suicide. An autopsy found he was on medication for depression.

Kevin Garner's divorce hearing was scheduled to begin the next day. His estranged wife, teenage daughter, and his wife's sister and niece were found shot dead in their home. Garner's body was found 70 miles away, in his house, which he set on fire.

After a fight with his wife, James Harrison fatally shot his five children, aged 7 to 16, in the middle of the night and then killed himself the next morning. According to police reports, his wife was involved with another man and was planning to leave him.
Wearing a bulletproof vest, Jiverly Wong, 41, entered a citizenship class and fired 98 shots from two handguns. Wong killed 13 people and injured several more before shooting himself.

As a family meal began, Devan Kalathat, 42, shot his wife and two children; his brother-in-law and the brother-in-law’s wife and infant daughter; and finally, himself. Only his wife survived. Police believe a feud fueled the violence.

Robert Kenneth Stewart entered a nursing home where his estranged wife worked and fatally shot seven elderly patients and a nurse. He said he had taken too many sleeping pills and could not be held responsible. He was sentenced to at least 142 years.

Four Oakland police officers, including two SWAT team members, were killed after a wanted man was pulled over in a traffic stop. Lovelle Mixon, 26, holed up in his sister's apartment and shot at police before he was killed. A fifth officer was injured.

A 14-month-old boy was spared in the slayings of a woman, her boyfriend and two of her nephews. Gevante E. Anderson, the woman's former boyfriend and the father of the child, was found guilty of first-degree murder and sentenced to life without parole.

A birthday party ended in violence when a woman's estranged husband burst into her house and shot her, her boyfriend, and two members of her family, police said. Guillermo Lopez, 48, set his truck and home on fire before he killed himself.

Chiew Chan Saevang, 38, and his girlfriend, Yer Yang, 40, decided to steal a drug shipment from their partner in an opium ring. At his home, they killed the partner's wife and three children. A week later, while fleeing police, Saevang fatally shot Yang and then himself.

Ten people died and six were injured after Michael McLendon, 28, went to several relatives' homes firing an assault rifle. According to a letter McLendon sent police, he was depressed he could not be a police officer or Marine. He committed suicide.

Scott Lamar Abbott has been hospitalized for mental health issues at least four times. He was sentenced to life without parole after stabbing his ex-girlfriend and three others 95 times. Prosecutors said he was angry about the breakup.

After leading police on a daylong manhunt, Davon Crawford, 33, shot himself as officers found him inside a West Side home. The night before, Crawford had killed his wife, his sister-in-law, two nephews, and his niece. He also injured his 7-year-old daughter.

Caleb Lacey, a rookie volunteer firefighter, was found guilty of setting a fire that killed a mother and her three children. Prosecutors said Caleb Lacey drove to the fire station and donned gear, wanting to be a hero. Lacey was sentenced to 25 years to life.

Frank Garcia, a nursing supervisor, was enraged at two co-workers who accused him of sexual harassment which caused him to be fired. Returning to the hospital, he shot three people, including a nurse and a bystander who attempted to intervene.  Garcia then drove 50 miles where he killed a couple in their home as their teenage children watched in fear.   Garcia was convicted and sentenced to life.

One week after losing his medical job, Ervin Antonio Lupoe, 40, killed his wife and their five children in their home and then committed suicide. In a suicide note, he wrote that he and his wife had agreed to the killings after she lost her job as well.

Joshua S. Durcho's girlfriend had threatened to call police on him, so he strangled her, and then strangled her four young children. Durcho, who had been in prison and vowed not to return, pleaded guilty and received five life sentences without parole.

Bruce Pardo dressed up as Santa Claus and went to his former in-laws' home during a Christmas Eve party. He shot and killed his ex-wife and members of her family before setting the house ablaze, killing  nine and injuring three others. Pardo then committed suicide.

Roberto A. Rojas went to his in-laws' house, where his estranged wife was living, and shot and killed his mother-in-law, son, and two stepsons. He shot and beat his wife, who survived. Rojas was sentenced to life in prison without parole eligibility.

Five men in a homeless camp were killed in a drug-debt dispute, police say. David Cruz Ponce and Max Eliseo Rafael each were charged with five special-circumstance counts of murder. Both pleaded not guilty and were convicted. Ponce was sentenced to death and Rafael was sentenced to life.

Five men entered a bar, intending a robbery. They shot three and, in the melee, a fourth man also was shot. Pedro Duran, 32, Renil Escobar, 29, Mario A. Funes, 26, Rigoberto Funes, 20 and Jose A. Cornejo, 22, all were sentenced to life in prison.
After losing his job and money in the stock market, Karthik Rajaram, 45, shot and killed his wife, mother-in-law, and three sons in their home. He then committed suicide.

A woman, her two sons, and one of the son's girlfriend were found dead in her home. They had been beaten and shot. Troy Brake, 31, was convicted of their murders and was sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole.
The bodies of a mother and her three daughters were found in their home. Corey King, a friend of the woman's son, was found guilty of four counts of first-degree murder and was sentenced to death.

Rolando Terrell and Lester Hayes were involved in a robbery during which they killed four people. They then set the house on fire in an attempt to cover it up the crime. Terrell was sentenced to life in prison while Hayes worked out a plea deal and received a 20-year sentence.

Using stolen guns, Isaac Zamora killed six people, including a sheriff's deputy. Zamora was sentenced to life and sent to a state mental hospital but later was returned to prison after doctors indicated he posed too much of a threat.

Luis Cruz shot and killed his wife, daughter, son, and mother-in-law before committing suicide as they gathered for Labor Day dinner. The killing was precipitated by a "fierce argument" with his wife, according to the police.

Five men were tortured, beaten, electrocuted, and slashed in what authorities said was a contract killing. Members of a Mexican drug cartel were angry over $450,000 that was missing. Six members of the cartel were sentenced to prison.

Authorities found four bodies after putting out a house fire. A couple had been shot execution-style. Two boys survived gunshots but died in the blaze. Two men were charged but found not guilty. The case remains unsolved.

A retaliatory shooting at a Fourth of July street party resulted in the deaths of four victims and injuries to two others. Antonio D. "Cheem" Williams and James R. Washington were convicted and sentenced to life in prison. Rosario C. Fuentez pleaded guilty  to four counts of first-degree reckless homicide and received a sentence of 20 years in prison.

Two men, a young woman and her 2-year-old son were beaten to death in their apartment. Nicholas Sheley was found guilty of murder. Sheley, who faces a trial in the murder of an Arkansas couple, is already serving a life sentence for two other killings.
Upset that his supervisor reprimanded him, Wesley Higdon shot his supervisor and five co-workers at the Atlantis Plastics plant, four of them fatally. Higdon then committed suicide.

Investigators found the bodies of a woman, her two children and her cousin. Her ex-husband Jae Hwan Shim led authorities to a fifth body in Mexico in late 2013. Shim and his friend Tae Won Kwon pleaded guilty, both receiving life sentences.

John David Young, 38, shot and killed his wife, mother-in-law and two children in the middle of the night, and then killed himself. Deputies had been alerted by the mother-in-law, who called police to report "He's killing us."

Salvador Alfaro, an immigrant from El Salvador, shot and killed a woman and three children in their home and then committed suicide. The woman also was from El Salvador, and they lived together as a family.

After an earlier disagreement with his father about coming home late, Nathaniel Dickson, 18, went to his brother's closet looking for clothes and found his brother's 12-gauge shotgun. He proceeded to shoot and kill his stepmother, stepsister, brother, and father. In his confession to police, he said "I don’t know why I killed my family today." He had experienced some personal problems prior to the killings, including moving back into his parents' house after breaking up with his live-in girlfriend and not getting into the Marines. He was sentenced to life without parole.

Three men and two women were shot in the head and killed during a Chicago burglary. The three suspects stole money, jewelry and TVs, police said. Torolan Williams and Michael King were found guilty and received life sentences. Arthur Brown pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 24 years.

Police found Jason Abbott, 18, on his grandparents' porch, a knife to his throat. Inside, they found his grandparents, his aunt, and her fiancé, all fatally stabbed. Another aunt survived. He pleaded guilty and gets schizophrenia treatment in prison.

Four people were found shot to death in Charlotte's Tree Top apartment complex. More than a decade later, a cold case investigation resulted in the arrest of Dominick Daise. Investigators believe the four victims were "involved in a lifestyle that put them in jeopardy."§  Daise was committed in 2019 and released in 2020. He was subsequently in and out of jail between 2020 and 2023 for various charges relating to assault, robbery, and drug charges.

Steven Sueppel, 42, beat to death his wife and four children before killing himself. Sueppel had been indicted a month earlier on charges that he had stolen more than a half million dollars from the bank where he worked.

Lee Isaac Bedwell Leeds, who had been diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia, fatally shot his father, two employees and a customer at his family's junkyard. Leeds said that he believed the victims were plotting to kill him. He was found competent to stand trial and was sentenced to 100 years in prison.

A house fire that the authorities determined to have been intentionally set resulted in the deaths of seven people, including three children. Security video suggested there to be two unidentified individuals who may have been responsible, but the case remains unsolved. The police suspected there to be a drug connection underlying the incident.

Jessie Dotson was convicted of killing his brother and five others, including two toddlers, after being released from prison five months for an earlier murder. Three other children were badly injured in the shooting, two of whom testified against Dotson. Dotson was convicted and sentenced to death.

Upset over breaking up with his girlfriend, Rusty Rumley, 26, went to her mother's apartment and shot and killed four people, including  his ex-girlfriend's boyfriend. Rumley then committed suicide when surrounded by police.

A 14-year-old boy called police to say his father had shot him and his brother. Police found a woman and three children dead in the home; the teenager survived his injuries. Orland Cho, 41, husband and father of the three, later shot himself.

Steven Kazmierczak, a 27-year-old former graduate student, entered a Northern Illinois University lecture hall during a class, shot and killed five people and wounded 21 before committing suicide.  Kazmierczak reportedly had a history of mental illness.
