Angry at city officials, Charles Lee "Cookie" Thornton, 52, entered a City Council meeting and began shooting, killing five, including two council members and two police officers. Months later, the mayor died of his injuries. Thornton was killed by police at the scene.

A month after being fired from his brother's moving firm, Edwin Rivera, 20, shot and killed his father, two brothers and a police officer during a standoff at his home. He was killed by a police sniper's bullet as he fled a fire caused by stun grenades.

The killer entered a Lane Bryant store on a Saturday morning and announced he was robbing the store. He ordered six women to the back of the store where he bound and shot them. Five died. The case remains unsolved.

Nicholas Browning, 15, used his father's handgun to kill his mother, father and two brothers while they were sleeping. He then went to a friend's house to play video games. He had been arguing with his father. Browning took a plea and was sentenced to life with parole eligibility.

Angry about two teenagers stealing his cellphone, Michael A. Davis set fire to their home. The blaze trapped two adults as well as four children, all younger than the age of 8. Davis was sentenced to  six consecutive life terms in prison.

A plan to steal marijuana and cash from a home ended in the shootings of two women, a baby, and a toddler. Five men were convicted in connection to the robbery and slayings. All five assailants pled guilty and were sentenced to prison for various terms ranging from 10 years to 245 years, the lengthier given to Ronald Davis, the gunman.

Michel Veillette, 34, hanged himself in jail while awaiting trial on charges that he stabbed his wife to death and then set fire to their house. The couple's four young children, all younger than 9, died from smoke inhalation.

After arguing with his wife, Vietnamese immigrant Lam Luong threw their three children plus his wife's child off the 80-foot Dauphin Island bridge to their deaths. Luong appealed his death sentence. He was then deemed intellectually disabled and his sentence was reduced to life in prison without parole eligibility.

A woman and her boyfriend fatally shot her parents and then also her brother and his family as they arrived for Christmas Eve dinner. Michele K. Anderson and Joseph Thomas McEnroe both were sentenced to life without parole.

Oliver Bernsdorff killed himself while driving across the Sunshine Skyway. Police found his ex-wife and her girlfriend dead at their home in Largo. At Bernsdorff's Clearwater home, they found the bodies of his two children, ages 4 and 2.

Four bricklayers were beaten, stabbed, and robbed in their apartment, 1,600 miles from home: Villa de Ramos, Mexico. Their roommate Santiago Moreno was convicted in Mexico, which won't extradite citizens facing the death penalty. He received a prison sentence of 120 years.

Matthew Murray, 24, was dropped from the missionary program of the New Life Church in Arvada, CO. Five years later, he returned and shot two people then drove  to the evangelical church where he killed two others before committing suicide.

A 19-year-old with an extensive history of mental health troubles entered Westroads Mall and began firing an assault rifle. Eight people died and four were injured. Robert Hawkins, who declared that "I'll be famous," killed himself.

A woman had twice asked the court to seize her ex-husband's long gun after she filed a protective order against him. David Peter Brockdorff, 40, used the .22-caliber rifle to shoot her and their three children before killing himself on Thanksgiving Day.

Investigators say Matthew Blixt, 17, used his father's gun to shoot his father, his father's girlfriend, and the woman's two daughters before turning the gun on himself. Friends said Blixt was upset that his father, who was separated from his mother, was dating someone.

Two children were among the victims of a shooting in what police described as a "known narcotics location." All four victims were shot as they slept. Patrick Albert Young Smith was found guilty of four counts of murder and sentenced to life in prison.

Deputy Sheriff Tyler Peterson, 20, barged into his former girlfriend's locked apartment during a party and shot and killed six people. Two others were injured, including a police officer responding to the shooting.  Peterson shot himself after a standoff with the police.

Kirby Archer, 35, and Guillermo Zarabozo, 19, chartered and hijacked the Joe Cool, a Miami-based fishing boat. They shot and dumped overboard its crew of four, planning to flee to Cuba. Archer pleaded guilty to murder and Zaraboso was convicted at trial. Both were sentenced to life in prison.

The case of Davontae Sanford, who at 14 confessed to killing four people and who later recanted, drew national media attention. Sanford, who is developmentally disabled, was exonerated after seven years in custody. Vincent Smothers, a contract killer, confessed in 2008 to these and other killings. Smothers was sentenced to 52 years in prison after pleading guilty in 2010 to eight other killings.

Paul Devoe shot and killed his ex-girlfriend and five others including two teenagers. Devoe was initially found incompetent to stand trial but after medication was deemed competent. Devoe was convicted of capital murder and sentenced to death.

Vonzell Roundtree, high on drugs, saw two men argue with his uncle in a Southwest Philadelphia bar. When he stopped firing his handgun, all three were dead. A fourth man died of his wounds a month later. Roundtree is serving four life prison terms.

Christopher Vaughn, 32, who wanted to abandon his family and live in the Canadian wilderness, pulled over their Ford Expedition on an isolated road and fatally  shot his wife and three kids. Vaughn was convicted and sentenced to life without parole.

Ambrosio Analco had threatened to kill his estranged girlfriend, the mother of his children. He fatally shot three adults and a pair of 6-month-old twins. His 1-year-old daughter survived her injuries. Analco then shot himself in the chest twice.

Sheree Dionne Murphy, a drug addict, argued with a motel tenant and set fire to the motel, killing the man, his fiancé, and several other family members. Seven people were injured. Convicted of murder and arson, Murphy received five life sentences.
Banita Jacks killed her four daughters by stabbing, beating, and strangling them. She lived with their bodies for several months. She was convicted of murder and sentenced to 120 years in jail.

Seung-Hui Cho, an "angry and disturbed" Virginia Tech senior, killed two students in a dorm before entering classrooms and shooting others. Thirty-two people were fatally shot by Cho, who then took his own life. A review of the case found that Cho's mental health history should have prevented him from buying guns.

Several hours after arguing with a man at a nightclub, Zachary Q. Meeks set the man's house on fire. Five kids -- ages 5 months to 10 years -- died. Meeks pleaded guilty and was sentenced to five consecutive life terms without possibility of parole.

Six members of the Wilcox family were found dead following a house fire. According to the authorities, 34-year-old Russell Wilcox, who reportedly was mentally disabled, had shot his family members, set fire to their home, and then perished due to smoke inhalation.

Two years after police found the bodies of three suffocated children, the body of their mother was found in a shallow grave 20 miles away. Pedro Rodriguez, 28, who was found hanged in the family's home, is believed to have killed all four.

Someone twice set fire to a trailer in a mobile home park. On the third try, five of 10 occupants died, in part because the owners had covered windows with wire mesh. They settled survivors' claims for $6 million. The case remains unsolved.

According to an FBI report, 8-year-old Sulejman Talovic "sought to kill as many people as possible" when he entered the Trolley Mall and began shooting. Five victims were killed and four others were injured. Talovic was killed by police.

Four young adults were found shot in the head inside a run-down house. The gunman had forced his way in. Police believe the shooting was part of an ongoing feud between two neighborhood groups. The case remains unsolved.

Richard Wilkinson didn't get along with his daughter and son-in-law, who lived with him. He argued with her and told friends they were stealing. One night, he shot them and his two grandsons, ages 3 and 6. As police entered his home, he killed himself.

Charles W. Gilleo Jr.’s plan to steal drugs from an acquaintance ended in the killings of the acquaintance, his wife, and their three children. Gilleo received five life sentences without parole eligibility, while his accomplice Mark S. Serrano was sentenced to 50 years to life.

In January 2007, police found the bodies of four homeless men dumped in manholes. They apparently had stolen scrap metal from the suspects. Daniel Joseph Sharp pleaded guilty and is serving a 65-year sentence. Randy Lee Reeder received a sentence of 260 years.
Hersel M. Isadore, Jr., 28, was "depressed and acting irrationally" in the weeks before he fatally shot his longtime girlfriend, four of their children, and a cousin. Isadore then committed suicide.

Terrance Robinson, 22, went into the house, stayed a few minutes, left briefly, and returned to shoot two men and two women, possibly because of an earlier dispute. He was sentenced to eight life terms without the possibility of parole.

Angelica Alvarez, 27, strangled her four children, ranging in age from 2 through 8. Psychiatrists debated her mental health and eventually she was ruled competent to stand trial. She was sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole.

Wayne S. Powell, 41, made good on his threat, pouring gasoline inside a home's side door, and lighting it. His ex-girlfriend, her mother, adopted son and a niece were killed. Powell was convicted and sentenced to death.

Authorities say a family dispute over an inheritance left four family members dead. Felton Bernard received a life sentence in the shootings of his uncles, an aunt, and her boyfriend. Corey Berniard was sentenced to 30 years in prison.

Angry over a fight, Valerie Moore set fire to a mattress outside a hotel room. The blaze spread through the Mizpah Hotel, killing 12 and injuring 30 others. Moore, who was convicted of second-degree murder in 1987, received 12 life sentences.

Auto mechanic Raymond Oyler, 37, was convicted of setting a wildfire that killed five federal firefighters. The 60-square-mile Esperanza fire also destroyed 54 homes and other buildings. He was sentenced to death in 2009.

A couple and their three teenage daughters were shot with a .22-caliber rifle. Prosecutors said Shawn Bentler, 23, killed his family to gain control of his parents' estate. He is serving life in prison without possibility of parole.

Three women and a man were dead inside a house after neighbors reported hearing gunshots. Earnest King and Kenton Williams were arrested the following month. In 2010, King plead guilty for conspiracy to commit kidnapping and was sentenced to 90 months in prison. The same year, Williams plead guilty to solicitation of capital murder and was sentenced to ten years in prison.

A couple and their two sons were killed at milepost 149 on the Florida Turnpike in a drug trade case. Gunmen Daniel Troya, 23, and Ricardo Sanchez Jr., 23, are on death row. Liana Lopez, 20, was sentenced to 15 years in prison. Their boss, Daniel Varela, 26, is serving two life terms plus 60 years.

Suspecting her of infidelity, Said Biyad, 42, beat his wife with a mallet and slit the throats of their four children, ranging in age from 2 to 8. Only his wife survived. Biyad was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

A mother, 19, her son, 2, her nephew, 17, and her father, 60, were found shot at their home outside Winchester, VA. Her former boyfriend, Jessi A. Jephson, 20, was found guilty and sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole.

Charles Roberts IV, 32, entered a schoolhouse in an Amish hamlet, dismissed the boys and bound the girls. He carried three guns, a stun gun, two knives, a hammer, and 600 rounds of ammunition. He shot 10, five fatally, before killing himself as police closed in.

Michael Simmons has been confined indefinitely to a state mental hospital. The bodies of his wife and her four children were found by a woman visiting their home. Simmons previously had served time in prison for robbing and beating a disabled man.

Four bodies -- three men and a woman -- were found in a Jeep in a Fresno residential neighborhood. They were bound with duct tape and cable ties. Police said they probably were involved in the illegal drug trade. The case remains unsolved.

Kevin and Raymond Amison were arrested after allegedly gunning down three brothers and a friend on a porch in New Orleans. The charges against Kevin were dropped following a mistrial while Raymond plead guilty and was sentenced to 10 years incarceration.

Conner Schierman, 24, entered a neighbor's house while the man was deployed with the Army National Guard in Iraq. He fatally stabbed the man's wife, two young sons and sister-in-law. He bought gasoline and torched the house. He is serving a life sentence without the possibility of parole.

Trevor Branscum, 38, had been drinking and argued with his wife at a market. Later that night, with his blood-alcohol level four times the legal limit for driving, he shot their four children with a rifle before killing himself.

A woman, her fiancé, her 16-year-old daughter and the fiancé’s 15-year-old nephew were gunned down by Frank Knight, James Bishop, and Kelvin Kaigler over a drug debt. Knight, 33, testified against Bishop and Kaigler, who are both serving life terms. Knight was sentenced to 15 to 35 years in prison.

A woman, 27, was shot in her home. Her three children -- ages 3, 5 and 10 -- were strangled or suffocated. Jason Howard, her former boyfriend, was named as a suspect by police, but the charges were later dropped. He was already serving time in prison on an unrelated murder charge and will be eligible for parole in 2050.

Five teens were shot to death while sitting in a car. An initial suspect, who maintained his innocence, pleaded guilty to lesser crimes after his conviction on the five murders was overturned. Authorities now believe that a Telly Hankton, a different individual who is serving a life sentence for other crimes, actually committed the massacre.

Desmond Turner, 28, and James Stewart, 30, were convicted of shooting seven family members in an attempted robbery and burglary at a home. The gunmen mistakenly believed that the family had drugs and money. Turner was sentenced to life in prison without parole, plus 88 years; Stewart, to 425 years.

Henry Lee Stringer, 34, torched a house, killing his two young kids. Firefighters also found their mother and grandmother fatally stabbed. He accepted life in prison without a chance for parole to avoid the death penalty but offered no explanation.

A woman driver was pursued by her ex-boyfriend and father of her child at speeds up to 120 mph. A crash killed her and four co-workers. Kevin Cales, 32, was convicted of the crime and was sentenced to 79 years in prison. Less than two months later, Cales died after being attacked by fellow inmate Waldemar Rivera, who was a cousin by marriage to one of the victims. Rivera was serving seven years for robbery at the time and got an extra 10 years in prison for the attack on Cales.
At his Baton Rouge, LA, church, Anthony Bell, 25, opened fire, killing four. He fled with his family at gunpoint. He killed his wife but released their three kids unharmed. He was sentenced to death.
The bodies of four adults were discovered outside a car in a recreation area near Phoenix International Raceway. All had been shot. There have been no arrests.

Upset over payroll deductions for child support, Herbert Chalmers Jr. 54, killed his ex-wife and an ex-girlfriend. He took a bus to the caterer where he was considered a good worker and killed the co-owner, her daughter and himself.
Jesse Wise, 21, beat and strangled his grandmother, an uncle, two aunts and two cousins. Surviving relatives asked prosecutors not to seek the death penalty. Wise was sentenced to life in prison.
After smoking crack, Ronald Shrieves, 32, stabbed his parents and a niece and nephew in Modest Town, VA. He pleaded guilty and was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

Four children--ages 3 to 8--died in a Cleveland house fire set by a man who was angry at their mother, a former girlfriend. Lorenzo Collins, 42, was sentenced to 111 years in prison. Collins Bennett, 39, his accomplice, also was convicted and given a 16-year sentence.

Kyle Aaron Huff, 28, attended a Seattle rave and an after-party at a house, then left. He returned with a handgun and a shotgun that he used to kill six people before killing himself. He left an assault rifle in his car.

Four out of seven people died after being shot or stabbed inside a Forsyth County farmhouse. Three assailants were arrested and convicted. Jason McGhee and Marcin W. Sosniak were sentenced to life without parole, while Frank Ortegon was sentenced to 20 years in prison.
Four Detroit residents, including a pregnant woman, were found shot at a vacant city-owned house that had been raided repeatedly as a drug den. No arrests have been made.

Arson trapped a mother and her two kids in an apartment building. Another woman died jumping from the fourth floor. Six years later, prosecutors charged Samuel Martinez with murder. In 2014, the charges were dismissed.

William Miller, 28, of Scottsdale, AZ killed two former employees who were working as police informants in an arson case against him. Healso killed three of their relatives. Miller was convicted on five counts of first degree murder and sentenced to death.

Three years after disability retirement for psychological problems, Jennifer Sanmarco, 44, killed a former neighbor. She then returned to her postal workplace and fatally shot six people before killing herself, all with a legally purchased handgun.

Ricky Gray, 28, was convicted of murdering a family of four during a burglary. His nephew, Ray Dandridge, 28, assisted. A week later, both men killed a family of three. Dandridge was convicted in that case and was given a life sentence. Gray also confessed to murdering his wife and was sentenced to death.
